informal statement: Let $A,B$ be Noetherian local rings and let $f: A \to B$ be a flat local ring homomorphism. Let $I = \mathfrak{m}_A B$ be the extended ideal in $B$. Consider the quotient (fiber) ring $B/I$ and the canonical quotient map $q: B \to B/I$. Since $f$ is local, i.e. $f(\mathfrak{m}_A) \subseteq \mathfrak{m}_B$, we have $I \subseteq \mathfrak{m}_B$, hence $B/I$ is still a nontrivial local ring. One checks that the maximal ideal of $B/I$ is the image of $\mathfrak{m}_B$ under $q$, namely $\overline{\mathfrak{m}_B}=\mathfrak{m}_B/I$.

Let $(A,\mathfrak{m}_A)$ and $(B,\mathfrak{m}_B)$ be Noetherian local rings and let $f: A \to B$ be a flat local homomorphism. By definition of a local homomorphism, we have $f^{-1}(\mathfrak{m}_B)=\mathfrak{m}_A$.
For an ideal $I$ of height $h$, there exists a subideal $J \subseteq I$ such that $J$ is generated by at most $h$ elements and $\operatorname{ht}(J) \ge \operatorname{ht}(I)$.

Let $I \subseteq J$ be ideals of a ring $R$. Then
$$\operatorname{ht}(I) \le \operatorname{ht}(J).$$
In a Noetherian ring, any minimal prime ideal has height $0$.

Let $R$ be a commutative Noetherian ring and let $I$ be an ideal generated by $n$ elements. If a prime ideal $\mathfrak{p}$ is one of the minimal primes over $I$ (i.e. $\mathfrak{p} \in \operatorname{Min}(I)$), then using localization: localize $R$ at $\mathfrak{p}$ to get $R_{\mathfrak{p}}$. The ideal $\mathfrak{p}R_{\mathfrak{p}}$ becomes the maximal ideal of this local ring, and its height is preserved. Hence we may assume $R$ is local and $\mathfrak{p}$ is its maximal ideal.

The height of a prime ideal $\mathfrak{p}$ is defined as the supremum of the lengths of all strictly descending chains in $\operatorname{Spec}(R)$ with top element $\mathfrak{p}$. In poset theory, the height $h(x)$ of an element satisfies $h(x) \le n \iff \forall y < x,\ h(y) < n$.
1分api: Ideal.height_eq_primeHeight, Ideal.primeHeight, Order.height_le_coe_iff, PrimeSpectrum.equivSubtype, Equiv.forall_congr_left, Subtype.forall

informal statement: Equivalence between ideal height and the height in the prime spectrum.
Equivalence between the prime spectrum and the set of prime ideals.

Let $I \subseteq R$ be an ideal and let $J$ be a prime ideal of finite height with $I \subseteq J$. If
$$\mathrm{ht}(J) \le \mathrm{ht}(I),$$
then $J$ is a minimal prime over $I$ (i.e. $J \in \mathrm{minPrimes}(I)$).

For a surjective map, one can always choose a subset of the domain on which the map is injective while keeping the same image. Concretely, there exists $u \subseteq s$ such that $f$ is injective on $u$ and $f(u)=t$.
If a map is injective and its image is finite, then the preimage set is finite.

Let $f: R \to S$ be a ring homomorphism, $I$ an ideal of $R$, and $K$ an ideal of $S$. Then
$$f(I)S \le K \iff I \le f^{-1}(K).$$

Let $S$ be an $R$-algebra. For an ideal $p \subseteq R$ and an ideal $P \subseteq S$, we say **$P$ lies over $p$** if $p$ is the preimage of $P$ in $R$:
$$p=f^{-1}(P),$$
where $f: R \to S$ is the structure map.
Monotonicity of the comap (preimage) operation.

Let $R$ be a ring and let $I,\mathfrak{p}$ be ideals of $R$. If $\mathfrak{p}$ is prime and $I \subseteq \mathfrak{p}$, then the image of $\mathfrak{p}$ in the quotient ring $R/I$ (i.e. the extended ideal $\mathfrak{p}\cdot (R/I)$) is again a prime ideal.
The rank of a span is bounded by the cardinality of the generating set.

Let $\mathfrak{p}$ be a prime ideal of finite height in a ring $R$. Then in $\operatorname{Spec}(R)$ there exists a strictly increasing chain of prime ideals of length exactly $\operatorname{ht}(\mathfrak{p})$ ending at $\mathfrak{p}$:
$$\mathfrak{p}_0 \subsetneq \mathfrak{p}_1 \subsetneq \dots \subsetneq \mathfrak{p}_n = \mathfrak{p},$$
where $n=\operatorname{ht}(\mathfrak{p}).$$
A surjective ring homomorphism induces an order isomorphism between the corresponding ideal lattices.
Let $\alpha,\beta$ be preorders. If $e: \alpha \simeq \beta$ is an order isomorphism, then $e$ is strictly monotone.
Proceed by induction on the length of a chain of prime ideals $l$ in a ring $R$.

Let $S$ be an $R$-algebra. We say $S$ satisfies the **Going-Down property** if: for any prime ideal $p$ of $R$ and any prime ideal $Q$ of $S$, if $p$ is strictly contained in the contraction of $Q$ (i.e. $p \subsetneq Q \cap R$), then there exists a prime ideal $P$ of $S$ such that (1) $P \subseteq Q$ and (2) $P$ lies over $p$ (i.e. $P \cap R=p$).

Assume $S$ is an $R$-algebra satisfying Going-Down. Given prime ideals $p \subsetneq q$ in $R$ and a prime ideal $Q$ of $S$ lying over $q$, there exists a prime ideal $P$ of $S$ such that (1) $P \subsetneq Q$ and (2) $P$ lies over $p$.

Let $\alpha$ be a preorder, let $p$ be an LTSeries in $\alpha$, and let $x\in\alpha$. If the last element of the series is $\le x$ (i.e. $\mathrm{last}(p) \le x$), then the length of the series is bounded by the height of $x$:
$$\mathrm{length}(p) \le \mathrm{ht}(x).$$
In a local ring, the Krull dimension is defined as the height of the maximal ideal.

Let $(R,\mathfrak{m})$ be a Noetherian local ring and let $k=R/\mathfrak{m}$ be its residue field. Write $\dim R$ for its Krull dimension and $\dim_k(\mathfrak{m}/\mathfrak{m}^2)$ for its embedding dimension. Let $n=\dim_k(\mathfrak{m}/\mathfrak{m}^2)$. Choose a $k$-basis $\{b_1,\dots,b_n\}$ of the cotangent space $\mathfrak{m}/\mathfrak{m}^2$. Using surjectivity of the quotient map, pick elements $\{x_1,\dots,x_n\} \subseteq \mathfrak{m}$ whose images in $\mathfrak{m}/\mathfrak{m}^2$ are exactly this basis.
With the above choice of $x_i$, show that their images generate the whole $k$-vector space $\mathfrak{m}/\mathfrak{m}^2$; this holds because they were chosen to be a basis.

Let $(R,\mathfrak{m})$ be a Noetherian local ring with residue field $k=R/\mathfrak{m}$. In a local ring, if the images of a set of elements generate the vector space $\mathfrak{m}/\mathfrak{m}^2$, then the elements themselves generate the $R$-module $\mathfrak{m}$.

Let $M$ be a module over a semiring $R$ and let $s \subseteq M$ be a finite set. Then the (finite) rank/finrank of $\mathrm{span}(s)$ is at most the cardinality of $s$:
$$\mathrm{finrank}(\mathrm{span}(s)) \le |s|.$$

Let $f: A \to B$ be a flat local homomorphism of Noetherian local rings. If both $A$ and the fiber ring $B/\mathfrak{m}_A B$ are regular local rings, then $B$ is also a regular local ring. By regularity of $A$ and $B/I$, their embedding dimensions equal their Krull dimensions.
In the situation above, take generators $x_A$ of $\mathfrak{m}_A$; mapping them into $B$ gives elements $f(x_A)$ generating $I$.
In the situation above, take generators $y_F$ of the maximal ideal $\mathfrak{m}_{B/I}$, and lift them back to elements $y_B$ in $B$.
In the situation above, **combine generators**: show that $\mathfrak{m}_B$ is generated by $\{f(x_A)\} \cup \{y_B\}$.

In the situation above, the minimal number of generators of $\mathfrak{m}_B$ is at most the sum of the embedding dimensions of $A$ and $B/I$; equivalently
$$\dim_k(\mathfrak{m}_B/\mathfrak{m}_B^2) \le \dim(A) + \dim(B/I).$$
